subject: Re: [junit] One Suggestion
msgSnippet: ... Yes. I always use the assertX() calls that take an error message string as the first argument. This is especially true for assertTrue() and assertFalse(),
messageBody:
joneira44 wrote:
> Hello EveryBody:
>
> I am using Cactus to testing my servlet application, and I fill the
> the result of testing is hard to understand, because you have to see
> the exception message to find which code's line ocurred error. So I
> thing one idea that is good for JUnit FrameWork.
>
> at any testing assert (like assertTrue, assertFalse, and so on..), we
> can put our testing parameters with the Name to indicate us the error.
>
> For Example:
> public void testYourNameAndMyName(){
> String myName="jose neira",
> yourName="jose";
> assertEquals(myName, yourName, "TestFirstName");
> }
>
> In the follor exception message:
> Error ocurred in "TestFirstName" at test your namen and my name.
>
> Now, I understand fastly where is error.
>
> do you think so?
>
> Sinceraly. Jose

Yes. I always use the assertX() calls that take an error message string
as the first argument. This is especially true for assertTrue() and
assertFalse(), which simply display "null" as the error message if you
don't supply one yourself.
